results.title: Making pottery. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Harvig Jensen and Hartvig Jensen Film Productions
results.brief_description: Shows how raw clay is processed in preparation for modelling. Demonstrations show a jug and a flower pot being made; creative use of engraving and decorating; the final firing and glazing processes.

results.title: Makeshift solutions
results.brief_description: Sixth in a series of nine animated films on the history of western civilization. Looks at the rise of capitalism during the 19th century; examines the formation of trusts, cartels and monopolies; and discusses the use of cheap labour and cheap raw materials.

results.material_description:

Magnaphonic full range sound system

41 Riley Street, Sydney

The British Thomson, Houston Co.  Ltd
Rugby, England (Made in England)
A.C. Motor
Type BKS 2408
HP 1/4
R.P.M: 1425
Volts 240/250
Cycles 50
Phase 1
Rating: Continuous
Cat no. D877416

The top case has a blue plastic reel with film inside it.
The bottom case has a red plastic reel inside it.
There is an orange rubber power cord nestled and rolled up in the middle of the unit.

Adjustments:  there is black duct tape holding in place a small box.  The unit has very much been modified by the previous owner.

Condition:
The rubber belt has begun to erode and crack, the belt behind that has also begun to erode.
There is black paint flecking away, particularly towards to top.
results.brief_description: One of two magnaphonic 35mm projectors donated by Bill Newman. Kerri’s father (name to be confirmed) has taken the projectors apart, cleaned them and re-assembled them. He has also repainted the lamp houses. Representative of early twentieth century Australian cinema equipment and history. These projectors were operated in Tumbarumba NSW, by William James Burnell Newman (Bill), who operated under Valley Theatres, from approximately 1959 until 1965, when TV started the demise of country theatres. These projectors were used in tandem as film rolls needed to be changed seamlessly during a session. The projectionist loaded all ‘even’ reels on one projector, and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector. As a reel was nearing its end, the projectionist had to switch over the film with perfect timing.

results.title: Magnaphonic 35mm projector
results.brief_description:
Magnaphonic 35mm projectors like these were used as a pair. During a screening, the projectionist seamlessly changed film rolls between projectors, loading all ‘even’ reels on one projector and ‘odd’ reels on the other projector.

This one was used in the small town of Tumbarumba, nestled in the shadow of the Snowy Mountains. From around 1959 until 1965, it was operated by William James Burnell Newman, who ran Valley Theatres. It’s representative of early 20th-century Australian cinema equipment and would’ve been used before TV kickstarted the demise of country theatres in the mid-60s.

constellations_primary.name: Cinema to superheroes
constellations_primary.description: This Magnaphonic Projector and its double were originally used in the Tallangatta cinema in the 1930s.

results.title: Magic Orchard
results.brief_description: Animated oriental fairy tale. A drought stricken village incurs further suffering when it is attacked by bandits. However, their luck changes when they find a pot of gold. The gold is used to buy some caged birds which, when set free, return to the village with seeds, from which grow a magic orchard. The orchard brings prosperity to the village, and its magic protects them from the bandits. (No narration or dialogue.)

results.title: Magic of nature. No. 3. The Ladybird
results.brief_description: Aphids, one of the most common and destructive garden pests, do much damage each spring to growing plants. Their enemy is the tiny carniverous ladybird which consumes them in large numbers. The film, using close-up photography, records the 8-week life span of the ladybird.

results.title: Maddingley
results.creator_credit: APM Productions, Atlas Associates and Cambridge Films
results.brief_description: A documentary film showing the brown coal mining process at Maddingley in Bacchus Marsh, Victoria, and then goes on to show how the coal is used for the production of paper at the Australian Paper Mills plant. Also includes scenes of the workers and their families of Bacchus Marsh at play.
